Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: I sat at the edge of the pool, my whistle hanging loosely around my neck, half-listening as my family chatted excitedly about our weekend plans. My little sister nudged me, her eyes bright, asking if I’d join them for a hike on Saturday. I knew how much it meant to her—and to all of them—that I be there, not just in body but in spirit, laughing and sharing stories. Just as I was about to promise I’d come, a sharp splash caught my attention. Across the pool, a group of teenagers were daring each other to dive right beneath the bold, red “NO DIVING” sign. My training kicked in; I was responsible for everyone’s safety, and I couldn’t ignore the risk. But my family’s expectant faces were turned toward me, waiting for my answer, wanting me to be present with them. My heart pounded as I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each impossible to ignore.
